How to Cite Frontiers in Psychology in APA Format

Complete guide to citing Frontiers in Psychology in APA 7th edition with examples, unique formatting requirements, and common issues specific to this source.

Frontiers in Psychology presents unique citation challenges that require specific guidance beyond general source type rules. This page provides targeted help for finding citation information, handling Frontiers in Psychology's particular format requirements, and avoiding common mistakes specific to this platform.

Quick Reference: Frontiers in Psychology Citations

Reference List Format:
Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx

Frontiers in Psychology-Specific Notes:
Citing articles from Frontiers in Psychology requires careful attention to detail, especially when listing authors. One unique aspect of citing this journal, as with any academic journal, is adhering to the specific rules of the APA 7th edition while recognizing any additional nuances that might arise from the publication itself. In APA 7th edition, when citing a source with up to 20 authors, all authors' surnames and initials are listed in the reference entry. This means for Frontiers in Psychology articles with multiple authors, students must include every author up to the 20th in the citation, separated by commas, with an ampersand before the last author's name.

A common point of confusion for students is the handling of the DOI in citations for Frontiers in Psychology. This journal often emphasizes the importance of including the DOI in its articles, which is consistent with APA guidelines stating that a DOI should be presented as a URL (e.g., https://doi.org/xxx). Students should ensure that they include this in their reference list, as omitting it can lead to incomplete citations. Additionally, students sometimes mistakenly abbreviate author names or incorrectly format the journal title, which should be italicized and written in title case.

To avoid these common pitfalls, students should double-check each author's name and the DOI, ensuring they adhere to APA guidelines by consulting the APA Manual or reliable online resources. It is also beneficial to use reference management tools like Zotero or EndNote, which can help manage citations accurately. By paying close attention to these details, students can ensure their citations of Frontiers in Psychology articles are precise and complete.

- Narrative: [Author] ([Year])

Where to Find Citation Information on Frontiers in Psychology

Frontiers in Psychology is a well-regarded open-access journal that provides comprehensive articles across a wide range of psychology topics. When citing articles from Frontiers in Psychology, it is crucial to gather specific information such as the author, publication date, title, and URL. Here‚Äôs a detailed guide on how to locate these citation details on the Frontiers in Psychology website:

  1. Accessing the Journal: Begin by visiting the Frontiers in Psychology website. You can do this by searching for "Frontiers in Psychology" in your preferred search engine and clicking on the link that leads to the journal's homepage.

  2. Finding an Article: Use the search bar at the top of the homepage to enter keywords related to your topic of interest. Alternatively, you can browse through different sections of the journal by using the navigation menu, which categorizes articles by research topics or article types.

  3. Locating the Author: Once you have selected an article, the author's name will be prominently displayed at the top of the article page, directly below the title. The author byline is often in a slightly smaller font and may include hyperlinks to additional information about the author(s).

  4. Identifying the Publication Date: Directly under the article title, you will find the publication date. This is typically presented in a month-day-year format and is crucial for your citation. The date is usually located along with the author's information, making it easy to spot.

  5. Finding the Article Title: The title of the article is displayed prominently at the top of the article page, above the author and publication date information. Ensure you copy the title exactly as it appears, preserving any special formatting such as italics or capitalization.

  6. Access Information and URL: The URL of the article can be found in the browser's address bar. Simply copy the full URL to ensure you have the direct link to the article. This URL is essential for readers who may wish to access the original source themselves.

Frontiers in Psychology is unique in its open-access format, allowing unrestricted access to all its articles. This facilitates easy retrieval of citation information, as you don‚Äôt encounter paywalls or restricted content. Additionally, articles often include a DOI (Digital Object Identifier), which can be found near the top of the article page, often below the publication date. A DOI is a permanent identifier that can be used in citations to ensure a reliable link to the source.

By following these steps, students can effectively gather all necessary citation information from the Frontiers in Psychology website, ensuring their academic work is well-supported and properly referenced.

Step-by-Step: Creating Your Frontiers in Psychology Citation

How to Create a Citation for Frontiers in Psychology

Creating citations for academic articles is an essential skill for any student or researcher. This guide will help you understand how to cite an article from the journal Frontiers in Psychology using the APA format. Follow these detailed steps to successfully create your citation.

What You Need

  • Access to the article you want to cite
  • Basic information about the article (authors, publication year, title, journal name, volume, issue, and page numbers)
  • A reliable internet connection to verify details or find the DOI
  • A word processor or notepad for drafting your citation

Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Identify the Authors

Action: Locate the author names in the article.
Verification: Check that you have the correct authors listed. The authors are typically found at the top of the article.

Time Estimate: 5 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: If there are multiple authors, make a note of all their names as they appear in the article.

Step 2: Determine the Publication Year

Action: Find the year the article was published.
Verification: Confirm that you have the correct year, which is usually located near the author names or in the citation information.

Time Estimate: 2 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: If the article is part of a special issue, make sure to note that year, as it might differ from the journal's overall publication year.

Step 3: Write the Title of the Article

Action: Write down the title of the article.
Verification: Ensure that you capitalize only the first word of the title and subtitle, as well as any proper nouns.

Time Estimate: 3 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: Use the title directly from the article to avoid typos or errors.

Step 4: Identify the Journal Name and Volume

Action: Find the name of the journal and the volume number.
Verification: Cross-check that the journal name is Frontiers in Psychology and note any specific volume number.

Time Estimate: 2 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: The volume number is often listed prominently in the article's header or footer.

Step 5: Check for an Issue Number and Page Range

Action: Determine if there is an issue number and what the page range of the article is.
Verification: Ensure that you have both the issue number (if applicable) and the starting and ending page numbers.

Time Estimate: 3 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: If the article has no issue number, you can skip that part in your citation.

Step 6: Locate the DOI

Action: Find the DOI (Digital Object Identifier) for the article.
Verification: The DOI is typically listed on the article's first page or in the citation section. If you cannot find it, use a DOI lookup tool.

Time Estimate: 5 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: You can also search for the article online with its title, which may lead you directly to the DOI.

Step 7: Assemble the Citation

Action: Put all the gathered information together in the correct APA format.
Verification: Follow the template:
Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx

Time Estimate: 5 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: Keep the template handy for reference as you build your citation.

Step 8: Review the Citation

Action: Double-check your citation for accuracy.
Verification: Ensure that all parts of the citation follow APA guidelines and that punctuation is correct.

Time Estimate: 5 minutes
Tip for Efficiency: Reading your citation aloud can help you catch errors.

Conclusion

Citing articles in APA format can seem daunting at first, but by following these steps, you will become more comfortable with the process. Remember to take your time during each step to ensure accuracy. With practice, creating citations will become a quick and easy task.

This section provides authentic citation examples from Frontiers in Psychology using recent publications from 2023-2024.

However, I can guide you on how to create APA-style citations for different types of sources based on your description and what you might expect to find. Here's how you might format citations using hypothetical examples based on typical scenarios in "Frontiers in Psychology":

Example 1: Standard Individual Author Article

Scenario Description: An empirical research article authored by a single psychologist on cognitive behavioral therapy's effectiveness.

Complete Reference:
Smith, J. A. (2023). The impact of cognitive behavioral therapy on depression: A longitudinal study. Frontiers in Psychology, 14(2), 150-162. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00001

In-text Citation (Parenthetical): (Smith, 2023)

In-text Citation (Narrative): Smith (2023) discusses the longitudinal effects of cognitive behavioral therapy on depression.

Notes: This is a straightforward example with a single author, showcasing typical empirical research in psychology.

Example 2: Corporate Author

Scenario Description: A report published by the American Psychological Association on new psychological assessment tools.

Complete Reference:
American Psychological Association. (2023). New tools for psychological assessment. Frontiers in Psychology, 14(3), 200-215. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00002

In-text Citation (Parenthetical): (American Psychological Association, 2023)

In-text Citation (Narrative): According to the American Psychological Association (2023), new tools for assessment have been developed.

Notes: This example demonstrates a corporate author, which is common for large organizations publishing research on behalf of their members.

Example 3: Multiple Authors

Scenario Description: A collaborative study examining the neural correlates of mindfulness meditation practices.

Complete Reference:
Johnson, L. M., & Green, T. R., & Lee, S. Y. (2023). Neural correlates of mindfulness meditation: A meta-analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 14(4), 300-315. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00003

In-text Citation (Parenthetical): (Johnson, Green, & Lee, 2023)

In-text Citation (Narrative): Johnson, Green, and Lee (2023) provide a meta-analysis of the neural correlates of mindfulness meditation.

Notes: This example illustrates how to cite an article with multiple authors, which is common in collaborative research.

Example 4: Special Formatting Case

Scenario Description: A special issue article exploring new methodologies in psychology.

Complete Reference:
Doe, R., & White, P. (2023). Innovative methodologies in psychology: Breaking new ground. Frontiers in Psychology, 14(Special Issue), 350-370. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00004

In-text Citation (Parenthetical): (Doe & White, 2023)

In-text Citation (Narrative): Doe and White (2023) explore innovative methodologies in psychology.

Notes: This example involves a special issue, which may require additional formatting, such as specifying the issue as a "Special Issue."

These examples demonstrate various citation scenarios you might encounter when dealing with articles from "Frontiers in Psychology." Be sure to replace the hypothetical data (e.g., authors, titles, DOIs) with actual information from the articles you are referencing.

Common Issues When Citing Frontiers in Psychology

Identifying Authors

The Issue:
Students often encounter difficulties in accurately identifying all authors when citing articles from Frontiers in Psychology. Articles can have multiple authors, and listing them correctly in the citation is crucial.

Why It Happens:
Frontiers in Psychology is a prominent open-access journal that frequently publishes collaborative research involving numerous contributors. The full list of authors is sometimes lengthy and can be overlooked, especially if students quickly scan the article header or abstract.

Solution:
1. Navigate to the Article's Page: Ensure you are on the article's main page, not just an abstract or summary page.
2. Locate the Authors Section: Scroll to the top of the article where the authors' names are listed. This is usually right below the article title.
3. List All Authors: In APA style, list up to 20 authors by their last name followed by their initials. Use an ampersand (&) before the last author. For more than 20 authors, list the first 19, followed by an ellipsis (...), and then the final author‚Äôs name.

Before Example:
Smith, J., & Brown, A.

After Example:
Smith, J., Brown, A., Johnson, L., & Doe, M.

Date Formats

The Issue:
Students sometimes struggle with proper date formatting, particularly when distinguishing between the publication date and other dates like submission or acceptance.

Why It Happens:
Frontiers in Psychology articles often display multiple dates, such as submission, acceptance, and publication dates, which can be confusing.

Solution:
1. Identify the Correct Date: The publication date is what you need for your citation. This is typically found near the top of the article or in the PDF version.
2. Format in APA Style: Use the year only in your citation.

Before Example:
Frontiers in Psychology. (2023, March 15).

After Example:
Frontiers in Psychology. (2023).

URL Handling

The Issue:
Properly including URLs in citations is another common problem. Students may either omit the URL or use incorrect formatting.

Why It Happens:
Frontiers in Psychology is an open-access journal, meaning all articles should be freely accessible online. However, students might copy the URL from the browser which can be long or include unnecessary session data.

Solution:
1. Use the DOI URL: Preferably, use the DOI (Digital Object Identifier) link, which is a permanent and stable URL.
2. Locate the DOI: This can typically be found on the article's main page or in the citation information section.

Before Example:
Retrieved from https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00001/full

After Example:
https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00001

Access Requirements

The Issue:
Students occasionally cite articles as if they require special access when they are, in fact, open-access.

Why It Happens:
Frontiers in Psychology is an open-access journal, but students sometimes mistakenly assume all academic journals require subscriptions or institutional access.

Solution:
1. Recognize Open Access: Understand that Frontiers in Psychology provides free access to its articles for everyone.
2. No Need for Access Date: Since the articles are always available, you don‚Äôt need to include the date of access in your citation.

Before Example:
Retrieved March 15, 2023, from https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00001

After Example:
https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.00001

By following these guidelines, students can effectively navigate the unique challenges of citing articles from Frontiers in Psychology, ensuring their work adheres to APA 7th edition standards.

Frequently Asked Questions About Frontiers in Psychology

Q: How can I navigate the Frontiers in Psychology website to find the citation information for an article?

A: On the Frontiers in Psychology website, locate the article you need to cite. Scroll down to the "Article Information" section, where you‚Äôll find essential details like the author(s), publication date, and DOI, which are necessary for your APA citation.

Q: How should I handle unique author formats when citing an article from Frontiers in Psychology in APA?

A: Frontiers in Psychology often lists authors with their full names. In APA format, list the authors by their last name followed by initials. If there are multiple authors, use an ampersand (&) before the last author's name in the reference list.

Q: How do I cite an article from Frontiers in Psychology when the publication date includes only the year?

A: If the article lists only the year of publication, include just the year in parentheses after the author(s) in your reference list entry. For example: (2023). Frontiers in Psychology generally uses only the year unless specific issues or sections are involved.

Q: What are the URL and access requirements for citing articles from Frontiers in Psychology in APA format?

A: Since Frontiers in Psychology is an open-access journal, include the direct URL to the article's webpage in your citation. Use a DOI if available, formatted as a URL (e.g., https://doi.org/...). Avoid using the database URL.

Q: How does citing Frontiers in Psychology articles differ from other journal articles in APA format?

A: Citing Frontiers in Psychology is straightforward because it is an open-access journal with DOIs for its articles, which simplifies retrieval. Unlike some other journals, you don't need to include database retrieval dates or subscription URLs, focusing instead on the DOI or direct URL.
